review_title: Hypocritical company values  with deep structural DEI and leadership problems
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: You will meet some talented and highly motivated individuals who truly do believe in TED's mission of spreading ideas "far and wide" and want to create a positive impact on the world.
cons:
- The structure of the company is too top-heavy with departments dropping and launching projects at the behest of the CEO. Work is completed according to the CEO's wishes and dreams as opposed to measurable and defined goals which leads to a chaotic and messy work environment with no room for innovation.

- You will fast learn that the concept and mission of the company is to create a space for wealthy white elites to gather together and discuss "ideas" as opposed to creating any positive impact on the world. TED Conferences is their annual reunion party where they're given the space to air out their special thoughts and opinions instead of taking action and doing something about it. 

- There are little to no meaningful career advancement opportunities, particularly if you're female/POC/of non-US origin. The system for promotions is unclear and often changes once you meet your goals on paper. Salary increases are few and far in between unless you are friendly with your manager, how hard you work and how much you execute does not matter here. You are expected to burn out, deliver more with decreasing resources, and when the failure inevitably happens you are blamed (unless of course, you are white, male, and middle class in which case you will fail upwards and be protected), 

- Leadership is abysmal, particularly on the Digital Products team. Managers who are in positions of power lack the crucial people management skills to do their job and manage their team. They are often passive when it comes to helping their direct reports with their problems, leading to a toxic environment where people act like everything is ok and bragging about their optimism gets them brownie points as opposed to acknowledging the very real problems at play. Identifying these problems marks you as a pessimistic non-team player so you better get on board with the toxic positivity. Favoritism of younger junior members is rampant as they do not know any better and their mediocrity is celebrated frequently.

- Attrition is very high (68% for one team alone) but there seems to be no accountability or acknowledgment of that fact, resignations are hidden behind fluffy "team announcements" and quickly brushed over. Retention does not seem to be a concern to this company despite the fact that many of the people who've left have been at TED for 7 yrs+ and are leaving with key institutional knowledge.

review_title: Sad to see it go downhill
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: You'll get to weather the storm with some really great colleagues. Health plan benefits are pretty stellar -- employer paid for employee on top tier plan.
cons: Lacks meaningful career advancement opportunities. Systems for advancement are unclear, complex and often change if you have met your goals and are ready for advancement. TED seems to go slow when helping you, but want you to do everything you can to help advance TED. For an organization with little do-or-die, it's a relatively high stress environment with limited tolerance of failure. One of those places where it's constantly "the way we've always done it."

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: In the public’s eyes, TED sheds light for those who thirst for knowledge and inspiration. It’s a great way to network with elites and thought leaders, if you’re part of the club. I joined TED for that very reputation it attained. But not only that, I’ve worked with some of the most kind, intelligent, and passionate people here. Hands down, you’ll never experience a better culture anywhere else. That is, until a large structural change in leadership had overturned it.
cons:
TED is mission driven only if it serves the new leadership’s interest.  They have no clue how to strategize their business goals. That’s because they don’t have any vision. And ideal team, to them, is top-down. To keep hiring more managers and agencies who can think *for* them without taking any responsibility. And the CEO could not care less about how any of us feel, as long as the spotlight is still on him. 

TED lost its ways. It’s sad to see how it turned out. We’ve been gaslit all along and it took this long for him to reveal his true colors.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: My immediate colleagues were great people who believed in working for a good mission.
cons: There is a huge divide between the core leadership team and the rest of TED. Overall team structure is very divisive and cross-team work can be very chaotic and combative. Leadership gives vague direction for the future ending up with failed attempts or rushed unorganized work. The unrealistic demands on deadlines cause long hours with only a couple days off as "reward". Everyone who joins TED takes a significant pay cut to work here for the mission. They want to have the TED name on their resume, but ultimately it's worth going somewhere else with a more positive environment that has qualified leadership in place and a higher pay. Power struggles combined with a gossipy workplace is creating a toxic environment that no one wants to be a part of. Lastly, the diverse representation at the leadership level is sorely lacking.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
1. Great Benefits
2. Good work-life balance
3. Nice individuals
cons:
- The company is experiencing high turnover due to poor leadership and a lack of clear direction. The CEO, Chris Anderson, is completely out of touch. As a small organization, senior leaders are treated with immunity for poor management and poor behavior. Diversity among upper management is also non-existent. 

- Bullying from people managers towards junior staffers goes unresolved and underreported due the small size of the organization, which does not truly allow for reporting to be anonymous without consequence. 

2. Understaffing and Growth: Rather than add resources, individuals are expected to excitedly take on more responsibilities without any promotion or salary increases. There is a lack of upward mobility for employees, which has resulted in high turnover. 

Working here is good for the name, but not for long term growth or morale.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Generous health insurance and benefits. 
The opportunity to meet incredible speakers and watch their talks live
There’s a lot of free food around the office for different events
It’s exciting to see TED content in the news and changing the world 
If you’re lucky enough to become a favorite of management, you’ll get numerous career growth opportunities 
The NYC office has great furniture, working spaces, views, and plants
cons:
There’s a white liberal culture. While some departments are great to work for due to their leadership, other departments have systemic race issues. Many teams are white with the most junior-level employee a person of color. Due to lack of advancement opportunities or mentorship for people of color, many often get tired and quit. Though leadership goes through the motions of talking about diversity, white fragility often prevails, and TED fails to make management and structural changes to make the workplace more equitable. 

The path to promotion is often unclear. Without clear expectations and regular feedback, many feel their hard work goes unnoticed and they feel exploited, especially since the pay is low. Over time, the lack of incentive to perform contributes to staff burnout. People come in idealistic and excited to work for TED but get frustrated with the lack of structure. Paired with the lack of structure is the problem of projects concocted on a whim by leadership with little thought into execution. With people stretched thin and thrown into projects at random times, team collaboration can become contentious. Throwing treats and a few lunches at the problem doesn’t solve the underlying issues. 

TED is glorious for those at the top making six figures and hobnobbing with celebrities. Many joined TED in the early days, and they are untouchable, regardless of how much of a bully they are, and how high their team’s turnover is. This, unfortunately, holds the organization back and might cause the company to stagnate. With 30+ having left the company in just the past six months, with the majority on the tech team, the company is in dire need of listening to its employees and rethinking its leadership team.

review_title: Amazing work culture, lack of career growth
job_title: Custom Content Creation Manager in New York, NY
pros: TED tends to hire really fantastic people who are smart and kind of interesting. Because of that the hiring process takes a while as you usually have to meet many people.  The opportunity to work at a TED Conference is pretty amazing and there's little lovely things they do to keep morale and foster culture. The staff retreat is pretty awesome and intimate. Not a company with competition within, people tend to be helpful and supportive and want to see each other succeed. Because of a strong company mission, staff carries that and even wants the same goal.
cons: Pay is pretty low- they are technically a non profit and capitalize on that with salary. There is no room to grow- you can do the same job for years and perhaps get a Senior title tacked onto it- but you'll be doing the same job. Managers are pretty terrible here as well- most people in general never received how to manage and TED is no exception. While the company grows, when it gets super busy, it still feels short staffed.

job_title: Writer in New York, NY
pros: Excellent company culture and mission. The people become your family and the org takes great care of its staff. Lots of fun projects to work on and decent pay for a non-profit.
cons:
Definitely not for the faint of heart. This is a fast-paced media company with a lot going on. Prepare to have one full time job year round and another job that you have to do for conferences.

The company is growing quickly and upper management is going through some major restructuring. This means that the vision and goals of the company are getting a bit turned on their head. Right now, the organization feels a bit aimless and messy but I'm sure it will shape up soon.

review_title: Shift in culture and limiting growth opportunities
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Great mission, purposeful work, overall great people. It's especially a fantastic opportunity to attend the conferences and meet interesting attendees.
cons: There is a major shift happening within the organization. TED is scaling and in the process losing its culture which is quite disappointing. Employees are being forced into positions they weren't hired for as there have been a lot of departures in the past 6 months. The new office has also created divisions among teams with everyone siloed in different spaces, feeling more like a corporate media agency.

job_title: Editor in New York, NY
pros:
TED is full of vibrant, enthusiastic young talent. Diverse young people come from all over the world to work at TED, throwing themselves into their tasks and forming a warm, supportive community. TED isn't a competitive atmosphere, and the content is enriching and fun to work with. For staffers lucky enough to attend conferences, the networking is incredible and the atmosphere is infectious. Going to a TED conference as staff is a once in a lifetime opportunity.

While some TED speakers are challenging to work with, the vast majority are humble, excited and genuine experts in their industries who are thrilled and grateful to collaborate with TED staff. 

The health benefits at TED are generous, and if you're lucky enough to become a favorite in the eyes of leadership, you'll receive a lot of opportunities to grow and experiment.
cons:
It's rare to see real advancement or mentorship. While TED regularly hires its interns, the practice locks these new hires in at very low salaries that help the company save money and make it difficult for them to negotiate competitively. Salaries vary wildly across the company, even for the same positions. TED's status as a nonprofit is used to explain away salaries that haven't increased in years, while senior leadership typically makes six figures. The fact that TED's Head curator does not take a salary (he also owns the organization) is used to obscure the fact that other members of senior leadership make nearly half a million dollars a year.  TED is a nonprofit only when it wants to be. There is strong pushback against anyone who raises labor concerns, from salary transparency to concerns about diversity, racism, classism or retaliation. TED talks a big game about its culture but fails to make actual changes that make the workplace more equitable. Policies around remote working, paid leave, flexible hours and vacation days are not enforced fairly across the company, leading to a disparity in how management is allowed to behave and how the rest of staff are treated and penalized. 

Management skills (or a lack thereof) are also an issue at TED. Problematic, inappropriate and abusive managers remain at TED for years without incident even as staffers flock to HR in droves to complain, or just quit. While some departments are great to work for due to their leadership, other departments have deep systemic issues with bullying, favoritism, intimidation and retaliation. Each department is its own kingdom with its own culture, and it's rare for leaders to face consequences for their failure to retain staffers or meet goals. Certain teams are well-known revolving doors with departure rates as high as 80%. When the sexually inappropriate behavior of executive level leader was exposed in the press, he was quietly removed from his team but not fired and is still a prominent member of the TED community. He continues to complain about his unjust treatment and make inappropriate remarks around staff.

The sad fact is that TED has strong talent but doesn't know what to do with it. Senior leaders remain at the company for years because the TED community is also their social life and they are well taken care of financially. The blurriness between TED as a community (of attendees, speakers and company leadership) leads to biased decisions made constantly about what "ideas" are important to highlight. Everyone outside of senior leadership leaves once they realize the hype of TED as a "family" doesn't extend past a dozen or so people at the top. This lack of change at the top of the company means there is little room for growth past a certain level for other staff, and creative thinking stagnates. Strategy changes are only taken at the whim of the CEO, with new initiatives announced every year that lack appropriate staffing or resources to succeed. This leads to the stretching of existing staff to accommodate an ever-expanding demand, and a serious issue with mission drift. Burnout is dangerously high and there's a large exodus of staff about once every two years. Staff concern about burnout and unmanageable workloads are met with eye-rolls and excuses from leadership. 

TED could be a thriving, successful company if leadership were willing to embrace change and recognize its own role in holding the company back.
